												Alpha Prime is basically an extended tech demo, clocking in at 5 hours of playtime. And oh boy, does it show.Let me get out the good parts first. As far as tech demos go, it looks pretty, with loads of cool effects on many interiors (outside doesn't look that good), and runs very nicely on my crappy laptop at 1280x800 resolution, except when there's too many particles (my NVidia G105M HATES them), you probably will run this perfectly. Also, ALL cutscenes are in-game, which is definitely a plus for both disk space and cutscene quality (seriously, ♥♥♥♥ those pre-rendered cutscenes)....and that's all the good points.As for the bad points, well... everything else.The story is not just completely forgettable, it's also accompanied by hilariously bad writing and voice acting. I'll sum it up nicely for you: Miner has to find artifact on Mars-like planet because of ♥♥♥♥♥ ex-girlfriend, shoot many things because CORPORATIONS ARE EVIL (also evil robots for no good reason), ♥♥♥♥♥♥ boss fight for the artifact, dead because your ♥♥♥♥♥ was a ♥♥♥♥♥ all along. Seriously. I did not give a single ♥♥♥♥ about the story, except for the hilarious parts, my favorite being Paolo, the Italian with incredibly bad engrish, getting shot in the leg and saying "No! Paolo go nowhere! Paolo is a cripple! Disability pension!". Too bad the game kills him WAY too early, clearly he should've been the protagonist instead.Oh yes, the gameplay. Enemies have perfect accuracy and INSTANT reactions, which makes even Easy a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ nightmare. Enjoy sniper shotgunners and exploiting their line-of-sight by leaning or crouching behind things so you become completely invisible to them.Literally none of the weapons are either balanced or enjoyable, and ALL of them have ♥♥♥♥♥♥ damage. The first weapon is a useless hammer, you can attack as fast as you can press the mouse button but you gotta be WAY too close, not to mention every single enemy has a ranged weapon anyway, so good luck not dying. The pistol shoots too damn slow and feels underpowered. The shotgun is one of the worst i've seen in any game, you have to be almost as close as the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hammer to do any decent damage (or any damage! Enjoy missing every shot while emptying all 8 shells!). The gatling rifle is the best one, which isn't saying much because it does ♥♥♥♥♥♥ damage and low ammo per clip. The sniper rifle would've been the best gun, had they not ♥♥♥♥ed up the zoom mode so badly that everytime you try to aim it's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ chore and you'll miss many shots because of it. Both the rocket launcher and grenades are hilariously bad because you need sniper-like accuracy for it to do any decent damage, because the splash radius is just TINY. And finally the Flamethrower... the worst weapon in the game, yes, even worse than the hammer, you have to be almost as close to anything despite the flame going at least twice the distance for it to do any damage, and what it DOES damage is absolutely pathetic, a mosquito would deal more damage than this.What else? The movement is hilariously broken, especially the jumping. They let you do a floaty jump but if you fall more than 5 meters you're pretty much dead. As for landing the jump itself, it seems to slide off things until it finds the flattest surface possible, it's really weird and it causes weirder deaths because of it. Because stairs are treated like ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ramps, I jumped downstairs and INSTANTLY DIED. And don't try to stand still either, because you'll slowly slide down that ♥♥♥♥ like's it's covered in butter. Also beware for anything with physics, it might just kill you, the most hilarious one is getting yourself killed by your own basketball. ON THE GROUND. JUST BECAUSE IT MOVED TOWARDS YOU. And finally, all the models barely look better than the ones on Doom 3, which is clearly what they were trying to mimic (some of them look just as ♥♥♥♥♥♥, too).Bottom line, just... don't bother. Only reason I even got this was because of a bundle. Spare yourself the torture.EDIT: Steam keeps putting this game on sale (I already regret making this funny), and I'd like to point out a few other things about the game, so here we go.This game has a lot of stuff that's so underused and generically/badly thought out, you can seriously tell this was a tech demo from the start and didn't actually evolve past that, they just made it longer.You get a hacking device early on in the game that lets you open locked doors and help you out in combat by making certain objects blow up... except sooner than you'd think, you'll never use it again unless you absolutely need to open a door. Zero combat use after a certain point.Yes, you can hack one of those silly remote-controlled box lifters at least twice during the game. Oh boy, just what I was missing from my favorite FPS game, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ box puzzles! Good thing I'll never see them again.Did I mention slow-motion? If you've paid any remote attention to the story, you know that stuff's Hubbardium, which is, you know... the very same reason that made everyone on the planet INSANE? And screw you if you think you deserve a good explanation for that (even in the end, it still doesn't make enough sense), so start pumping that ♥♥♥♥ into your veins and enjoy the orange effect.And finally, yes indeed, you do get to drive a vehicle in one of the final parts of the game, with decent physics to boot (as far as martian-like physics go anyway). But once more, it was badly thought out to the point that you'll only get a brief section of it and never see it again. Come on, split that stuff out evenly.Oh, and since people want to know the fun parts of the game, here's my list of screenshots, containing most of the amusing parts in the game. 												Alpha Prime is a terrible game, and I kind of like it that way.It's chock full of awful encounters, you fight the same three enemies the entire game, half the guns are useless and the other half only slightly less so, and levels seem to stretch on endlessly as they blur together. "Balance? To hell with that" you can hear Black Element yell as a barely discernible enemy on the other side of the room head shots you with a shotgun. Elements from other games are unglamorously fitted into parts of the game, like a patchwork quilt of design that's been out of style for years and manages to be significantly worse still than what they were lifted from.There do not currently exist words in the English language strong enough to properly describe the true horror that is Alpha Prime's writing, such an elongated mess of horrendous characters, dialogue unfit for a B movie, plot lines thrown out and then just left there, and a bit of casual misogyny thrown in just for flavor. It's agonizing to listen to, stilted voice acting keeping it from even being somewhat amusing, and there is so, so much of it.Alpha Prime is bad; a masterwork of mediocrity at the best of times. But again...I kind of liked it, maybe because for as miserable as it most certainly is, it's strangely polished in ways that made it kind of endearing if only ever so slightly. It feels like a game that might have been an obscure hit a decade ago, and I guess part of me still enjoys the sort of game that is so unmistakably rubbish, but its developer still clearly put a ton of effort into making it so I'm willing to go along for the ride even as I ask myself what is wrong with me. It's not broken, well, mostly. It's just bland, tedious, uninspired and a posterchild for dreadful videogame writing (though I will definitely be using "total lamers" as an insult).Can I recommend it? Probably not. Would I play it again? Not on your life! Do I regret playing it? I wouldn't say so.

												I have nearly 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews.One Hour Reviews - Game 6Alpha PrimePurchase Date: 1/16/2014Alpha Prime is another game I picked up thanks to a Humble Bundle.  18 months later I am finally getting to check it out.  Turns out I could have waited.Alpha Prime starts out much like one of those B-movies you expect to see on the Sci-Fi channel, with a bit of a cheesy story and some bad acting.  After listing to a laughably bad impression of a drunk guy, I meet my ex-girlfriend and get an exposition dump to explain the start of the game.  So about the first 10 minutes of my hour long review is spent in the opening cutscenes.Eventually though I end up on a planet and find myself in trouble in no time.  I quickly discover this game has all of the hallmarks of a standard shooter.  It starts me with a crappy melee weapon and slowly but surely I find better weapons to upgrade to.  And it's all the weapons you'd expect to see from pistols, to shotguns, to assault rifles and grenades.Along with some rather bad acting and dialogue, everytime I would pick up a weapon, the game would tell me "Picked Pistol".  Not picked up.  I started to feel like I was playing Pokemon.  Pistol, I choose you!  Shotgun, I choose you!The enemy AI seemed pretty dumb, although they were all good shots, so it still added some difficulty to the combat.  You definitely want to quick save the game often, as you will be reloading a lot.  But not necessarily because you died in combat.  Once I had to reload because the entire game crashed.  Another time I was crawling through an airduct (another hallmark of a first person shooter), and I somehow managed to crawl through a fan without the game registering a collision.  So I kept crawling through the airduct but then I ran out of level, and fell out of the world.  Some games when you fall out of the world it will 'reset' you to a nearby save spot.  This game just kills you dead.The game lets you interact with items in the game, although most of the time it serves no purpose.  There was one time I had to drop a sheet of aluminum over a hole in the floor to run across it.  A few times I opened up air ducts or lockers.  But a lot of objects were just randomly lying around like books or boxes.My favorite though was the random basketball I ran across.  Not only that but I found it in a room with a basketball hoop.  I wasted several minutes trying in vain to make a shot.  It's hard to actually throw items in the game.  All you can do is drop things, but if you happen to be moving your mouse as you drop it, you can kind of 'fling' things around.  In the end, all I succeeded in doing was get the basketball stuck in mid air.  I even tried shooting it down with my assault rifle, but it wasn't going anywhere.Between the crash, the glitches, and the bad dialog, you're probably thinking this isn't a very good game, and you'd be right.  The only charm it has is in that B-movie vibe you get from the story, but even then it's pretty cheesy and there are some gaps in logic that make it hard to ignore.Like Pablo.  Pablo is a character you meet, who is kind of charming with his broken English.  He gets shot during a cutscene and goes on about his shot leg and how he can't go with you.  Then the cut scene ends, and there is Pablo standing up on both legs, watching as I leave.   Meanwhile, 5 feet away is a med station.  I guess the med stations don't work on bulletholes in legs or something.It's not so much that I dislike Alpha Prime, but there's really just nothing particularly redeeming about it.  There are simply much better games out there to spend your time on.Overall Recommendation:  Pass

												Based on the reviews, I was expecting a really badly made game. However, I was somewhat surprised. Sure, Alpha Prime is nothing extraordinary, but it's not crap by any means either.It's a standard corridor FPS with a story. If you like FPS games, there is nothing to complain about here, aside from perhaps the difficulty being a bit too high. I've played on Easy and even then some sections were unusually hard and caused me to die many times.The story isn't bad either. Again, it's nothing groundbreaking, but for an FPS game it's pretty decent. Most FPS games don't make anywhere near the effort in the story department as Alpha Prime does. The cutscenes and the radio dialogue sections between the characters were a nice addition to keep the game interesting. Most characters were developed reasonably well in terms of personality.The graphics are very nice. Considering the game came out in 2007, those are pretty decent visuals, even by today's standards. The music is also not bad. There are only about 1 or 2 jarring heavy rock tracks, but the rest of the soundtrack is pretty good and gives a nice epic feel to the battles.The enemy variety could've certainly used some work. You spend a good 80% of the game just fighting spec ops, which gets repetitive eventually. There are some other gameplay sections added too, like hacking, and using a loader to move boxes out of the way, which is a nice change of pace, even if some sections were quite annoying. The loader in particular was difficult to control, and having to move a dozen of boxes out of the way just felt like a waste of time.In general the game is not as bad as the reviews claim it to be. It's just a standard, above average FPS that will keep you entertained for a few hours. If you are into the genre, give it a try, otherwise pass it up.

												I figured I'd write a review in case you have some spare coins and are looking for a cheap game.I've played through this twice so I know this game and some of it's problems.In short: This game feels like a mod for Doom 3.First off, the game is really linear and doesn't sport much exploration. There are a few exceptions; secrets and alternative routes. Good level design helps very much in this regard as each area feels pretty well thought out and assets doesn't feel overly repeated.I thought level design was pretty good. What messes things up is the scripted stuff. I.E take the wrong route, the jump-scare-enemy bugs out and crashes your game... twice.. or until you enter the room through the expected entrance. If you spot enemies and shoot them from afar, an elevator might not come down because the enemies the were scripted to use it and bring it down, thus, you'll have to reload to an earlier savegame.Unfortunately, stuff like this screws the game up badly. Use quick-saves often.This game is pretty weak on the story, which is delivered by some of the absolute worst voice actors I've heard. There are no exceptions. In fact, it's so bad it gets good. Ironic as it is, I laughed through the cut-scenes. Not much of it makes sense. Theese things, though unintentionally, serves as a comical break between game-play. It just feels funny.. for some reason. Brilliance in it's own, accidental way.Difficulty wise, the game is schizophrenic. You'll have a complete breeze throughout the first third of the game. Braindead A.I. This gets compensated as the soldiers appear. It's not easy any more. The difficulty suddenly sky-rockets through the roof. It's braindead A.I but with pinpoint accuracy. Regardless, it's a challenge.This game also features a hack system. You can hack surveillance cams, turretguns and locked doors to reach secret areas.Hacking is really only required once, and that is to open a door. Everything else is solvable without it.Vehicle sections in this game is bad. You'll want to get them over with as soon as possible. Thankfully you won't have to do it much.Alpha Prime is not a game with a limited two-weapon system, you can actually carry the entire arsenal. However, you are most likely to use the assault rifle.. It's way too overpowered compared to the other weapons. You'll only use the sniper rifle when the distance requires a scope, otherwise the assault rifle is about as accurate, holds more rounds and fires more rapidly.In close quarters, you'd normally favour a shotgun, but a two shot burst with the assault rifle is just as good and ammunition is plentiful. The use of explosives is rarely ever called for, and in those situations, they are so unreliable you might be better off with the assault rifle even in these situations. Lastly, the embarrassing axe that leaves bullet-hole decals on walls. It fires as fast as you can click your mouse button. It's completely broken. Luckily, you'll never ever find use for it. It's exists just for the sake of it.In terms of graphics, this game can't compete with the mainstream contemporaries of it's time (which would be Bioshock or ... Crysis). Rather, this game looks like a bright Doom 3, which means it looked dated even at release. But as this game is old and has a low pricetag, that shouldn't matter now.Sound assets works. Nothing really special to mention here. None of the weapon-sounds makes them feel punchy enough, but the overall ambience is doing it's job rather well.So, overall, this game looks and feels like a non-scary Doom 3 mod. It's kind of a B-graded game that certainly has it's problems. But if you are ready to overlook that and just take it for what it is, (a game that's actually cheaper than a subway sandwich) you might have good time with it. I know I had.I like it for what it is.Cheers!

												I would call this game decent in almost every aspect. The graphics are not bad for a 2007 release I think. OK, it's not Crysis but that game was way ahead of it's time. Compared to the more typical games from that year, it holds up well. The sound is probably the weakest part of the game. Guns and other sound effects are really not that interesting.There are quite a lot of cutscenes with spoken dialogue in the game. Storyline and voice acting is again, decent. Certainly not the on the level of the more big budget releases but that's ofcourse understandable. I've seen and heard worse. The AI baddies have very limited dialogue. The "Go go go!" and "Quickly fallback!" can get on your nerves quickly, especially when you encounter larger groups. Just kill them... quickly (or fallback :) The game lends some aspects of some well known FPS games, like the resupplying of health from dispensers on the walls, like in Half-Life. (So no health regeneration) The slowmo from F.E.A.R. although it doesn't seem to work that well, like in F.E.A.R. I ended up not using it that much. Along the way you pickup various weapons. Nothing like we've never seen before. There's a melee weapon, pistol, shotty, machine gun, a sniper like weapon, flamethrower and rocket launcher. Oh and of course, your grenades :)Don't expect this game to be a walk in the park. It can be really challenging on normal or hard difficulty. The AI is deadly accurate and you take a lot of damage really fast. It can lead to frustration fast if you are not careful enough.  It's not a game were you can storm into every room Rambo style to shoot everything that moves. Luckily you can quicksave the game instead of having a checkpoint system. You can also hack security camera's, often giving you the ability to see what's in another room. There's also the ability to lean, wich works well and is a welcome addition to this type of shooter.  The game doesn't do anything new or something that you will remember for years to come. It's more of a short blast. If you are into a more simplistic shooter, with above average difficulty, this is an interesting game to look at. Especially giving the fact that the game barely costs anything.

												Is this game worth the full asking price?  No, probably not. There's simply too many other, better games out there to be had for the same price.Is this game fun? Sure it has it's moments. At times it feels more like a strategy game than a straightforward shooter.At no time in this game can you do anything even resembling what is shown in the videos above, as far as running around jumping at enemies throwing grenades and shooting rampantly. You will always be low on HP, and low on ammo. The enemies always shoot first and they never but rarely ever miss. Most of them take 8-10 shots to the face to kill, and they come in groups.The weapons are frustratingly bad. Others here have mentioned how incredibly terrible the shotgun is, and I agree, for a game anyhow. Most FPS players are used to an overpowered unrealistic shotgun. In the MW and COD games you are using a rifled barreled fully choked military grade weapon. In this game, the shotgun is basically a sawed off shotgun from a seedy pawn shop. Surprisingly is shoots very similar to a real sawed off shotgun, but that doesn't mean it should ever have been put into the game this way. You'll need to be no farther than about 15 feet from your target if you hope to even hit it. About 6 feet if you hope to kill anything. It's just frustrating. Especially since the game keeps giving you ammo for the damn thing, over and over and no ammo for the assault rifle, which itself is pretty underpowered.  I found myself going for my pistol, over the shotgun, because the pistol is so overpowered compared even to the AR that it's kind of silly. Too bad you rarely get any ammo for it.The best gun in the game by far in my opinion in the sniper rifle. Though throughout the entire game, you'll only get about 40 rounds for the thing, and all but the lowest enemies require 2 or 3 shots to the face to kill with it. Why is it my favorite? I don't know, I guess it's the only one of the weapons that almost felt like it was done right.The grenades are a joke. You can toss one 4 feet from a guy, and he won't even go into the damage animation.You literally have to hope the grenade lands at his feet, preferably ON his feet if you want him to die.I suppose I should mention there is a Flamethrower, a Rocket Launcher, and a Hammer for a melee weapon.No real reason to mention them though. On several occasions I hit an guy in the face with a rocket, and he didn't even care. I'm sure it did some damage, but it's comical to see such a huge explosion, and out of the fire and smoke the guy is still shooting at you.The Flamethrower has the range of a hairspray can lit with a lighter. It's sometimes funny to watch the flame thrower enemies shooting flame at you from 8 feet away and you not taking damage. It's not so funny when you're the one using it though. Also it's comically underpowered. A complete botch of a weapon and no surprise, there's plenty of ammo to be found for it. The game also hides the damn things in secret rooms, as if it's some super weapon you'd actually want to use.The Hammer is your melee weapon.It's so pathetic that it even exists that it's hard for me to find words as to describe why it's even in the game.Enemies shoot you with unmissable headshots from hundreds of yards away, and the game gives you a frigging hammer.Do I even need to mention it's uselessly underpowered?The levels are passable. They are strictly linear affairs, which isn't uncommon. The amount of unused and useless rooms was probably meant to give the game some feeling of depth, but to me it just felt unfinished.The platforming parts of the game are stupid. This game should not have them. The jumping is beyond bad. Your legs are made of glass, because if you fall or jump from more than about 6 feet you will die. I'm no badass weapon weilding space marine like this guy but I've somehow managed to survive jumping off the side of a pickup truck. That would be death for the hero of this game.The physics in the game are annoying. Throughout the game, most things you grab will fall through the floor, or go into a frenetic jiggle spazm until it flies across the room, only to then sink into the floor when it comes to a rest. It was kind of cool to have to take the lid off of boxes to see what was inside though. Unfortunately of the hundreds of boxes in this game, only about 10 have anything in them. Which lead me to beleive the location for the game is a facility to mine and store Empty Boxes.There's an F5 quicksave feature that eventually becomes so necessary that you become glad it doesn't take but a second or two for it to save. I found myself killing one enemy, hitting save, killing another, hitting save, etc.So why am I giving this game a thumbs up?Truthfully, it's a bad game, but I had fun in spite of myself. Plus there's 90% off Steam coupons to be had which means you can experience the pain of this game yourself for only 50 cents. It's hard to pass up anything for that price.If nothing else, you can have the experience of what an FPS game is like when you do nearly everything wrong in making it.

												Alpha Prime is a Sci-Fi FPS based on a space station (a mine for a rare, new mineral called habardium.. or something) which has suffered an accident and on which there are only a handful of survivors. You have been sent in at the behest of your ex in order to save their current husband to be from the station.The game plays somewhat like an inferior Fear, having sci-fi weaponry and the ability to slow down time for a short while, but the guns in the game feel very underpowered. The assault rifle is the only weapon that is of any worth - the sniper rifle, shotgun and pistol doing practically no damage and being inferior in every situation to just tap shooting from the assault rifle. For 10 rounds you can kill an enemy which may take a second or two, but two shotgun blasts will take perhaps double that - and the shotgun is only able to be used at close range, where your health will vanish pretty quickly.The game is pretty unforgiving in some places with the combat. Your slow motion doesn't recharge on it's own and requires the mineral harbidudmidmm (you know, the mineral that's being mined on the station that you're turning into your own battlezone) and a single enemy, unchecked, can easily kill you. Additionally, ammunition for the assault rifle is pretty hard to find, even though it drops off of the enemies that you kill, meaning that a tight spot might grow tighter.The game has aged to a far greater degree than Fear, whilst the Unreal 2 engine's physics and lighting standards are still adequete enough, the physics in this game leave much to be desired. Ragdolls seem to go through objects sometimes and get stuck in them, the ground is often littered with random objects which you can easily get snagged on and the lighting seems hardly like a step up on DOOM. TL;DR it sucks

												Alpha Prime is not a bad game, it's just boring. When I started playing it, I expected something Doom-3-esque, with elements of thriller and an atmosphere of a dead mining station, and first couple of levels looked exactly the same, but 30 minutes into the game it became dull. I really appreciate the fact that you can die fairly easily if you are not careful and an encounter with two enemies is already a problem, but it's done the way you wouldn't want it to be: enemies absorb bullets like sponges and can survive even after half of a machine-gun clip is shot in their head. The other problem is a permanent lack of ammo towards the end of the game. "Hardcore" you may say, "Bad game design" i may reply. This game also has some interesting features, like hacking system, and it's a shame that it hasn't been developed enough anв there's almost no use in it, except the parts where you must hack something to proceed further into the game. The last, but not the least problematic thing is the plot: it is silly, illogical, predictable and even naive, not to tell that voice acting is fairly below average (seriously, I couldn't keep a straight face while listening to that Italian guy). I found myself enjoying playing some of it's parts and rather liked than disliked the game overall, but I'm almost sure that you won't. Every gamer has his own standards and mine are low enough to play this boring piece of crap and even don't mind some of it's major problems, but seriously, go play Doom 3 or Escape from Butcher's Bay, or FEAR instead, they are worth your time much more than this.

This game is a standard budget FPS with lame plot and dumb yet unforgiving enemies. You know how in Max Payne you trigger bullet time while falling so you gently soar like an oak leaf in October , but you still can aim with almost the same speed as outside bullet time , and your bullets travel a little bit faster than the enemy's. Well you wont see that in Alpha prime. In bullet time you move and shoot just as slow as your enemies , you still aim at normal speed , but it seems the AI does too. What you can , and should use are the lean buttons. Yep , [Q] and [E] are going to be your best buds again after all these years (ok you might have used E for Use , its bound to F now). 												Game was a nostalgic blast for me. Solid shooter that clearly takes its influence from the Half-life 2 style era while looking like a prettier and more optimistic Doom 3. However it honestly has better gunplay than both. ADS, peeking, solid hit detection, good feeling to the guns, and challenging shoot outs with an optional bullet time element and some occasional triggerable eviromental bits through the game's "hacking" feature. The game is also a lot of fun with how it lets you toy with the world around you with some gimmicky but fun physics that range from lifting lids off of crates for ammo to simply playing basketball in a gym room. Oh and no regenerating health, you find your supplies across dispencers and pick-ups like it should be done giving the game more depth and challenge. Its mostly raw solid gunplay and shooter action following familiar mechanics that works out pretty well. The game also has some of the best music I've probably heard in a long time from an FPS game, and the best part is it's free on their website.The game attempts a story, but the less said about it might be for the best as it really isn't that great and far from the highlight of the game. By the end the plot seems a bit confused of itself and ends on a note that will likely just leave you scratching your head. Meanwhile another thing worth noting on the downside is that several of the game's special mechanics get a little underplayed on the last two levels with the bullet time recourse running low, and hackable objects basically removed from battles. The game is also critcized for near perfect AI aim, which is true but honestly I think it actually added to the fun. Peaking around corners and trying to hit headshots before they shot back at me was just a part of adapting to the gunplay and felt natural. The AI also moves around, doges, calls out orders, and fliches to damage also giving them more life and opening them up to weak points making their aimbot skills more tolerable. At the end of the day I really enjoyed this game and it kind of made me sad we don't get games like this anymore. It had a weird plastic sci-fi feeling with amazing industrial techno rock music that felt right and sort of felt nostalgic of the 90's/early 2000's while giving me gameplay from a better era of corridor shooters. I'd recomend this game to people who grew up around an earlier era of FPS, or just want a bit of an escape from the current market for a good cheap action packed FPS. I suppose you could look at it as a cheesy fun comfort game in that regard. Oh and again, its cheap... $5.... considering people are buying retro 2D torture platformers for double or more, I'd say this is a steal of a deal by comparison.

One momment you're jumping into a large areana killing guys and then heading upstairs only to be stopped half way up to talk about interpersonal relationships with a girl who has you in a cuckhold.. which brings me to my next gripe.The story is bad. It does a poor job of trying to explain itself. I felt like it could have been really awesome. In the begining I was actually interested. You first land on the planet and you get a hard Bioshock vibe. These old miners are addicited to this mineral and they fight anyone who comes near. (Sounds like ADAM and Splicers, right?) But the game quickly throws these enemies out and replaces them with the same 4 cookie cutter enemies for the rest of the game.  The relationship between the main protagonist and the girl changes so often, one moment he'd die for her and the next he's complaining about her demanding nature... pick a side fella.Sides, theres another gripe I have with the game. The game gives you 3 characters that are on your "team". The only thing they will ever do in the game is talk to you over the radio. Once you actually meet any of characters they are quickly written off in various ways, never do you actually fight along side a team mate..... but this is probably due to the fact that the games AI is ridiculous.The AI can notice you from across the map at points in the game, which completely ruins the level designs because in the levels on which you are fighting on a two floor arena the enemies on floor oposite of you will notice you immediately and engage with you. So instead of having two equal difficulty floors you have one giant arena with enemies coming from all around.Quick final gripes:* The script is far to on the nose, reminds me of classic horror films where scientists would make wild very detailed conclusions that would end up being 100% true.*  The Flame thrower is the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ cousin of the weapons family in this game. 												Keep in mind, just because I'm voting "recommend", doesn't mean you should actually play it by my recommendation,  I just don't feel like a red thumbs down is very fitting of this game. If you have this game or have access to it for free, I would say go for it, but don't pay money for this, your time will be better spent on another FPS... or you know... in the real world. The storyline is sort of bland: Arnold, your silver fox, body builder, genius badass is mining a mysterious radioactive ore on some planet in some fictional universe with humans. He is the only one not being driven mad and so you have to shoot your way out of the space ship and blah blah standard Sci-Fi FPS.Spoilers ahead???The differences: Oxygen depletion happens when you're not in a sealed structure or breathing directly through an oxygen mask on a wall. When outside, you have to move quickly and get to the next oxygen mask to strategically plan your next move. You can also save at any time and will probably need to do that a lot because of how often you die. There are a standard set of guns, although the flamethrower is sort of sadly useless... There are some cool tech gadgets, where you can hack cameras and mines through the walls before entering a room. Some missions require you to carry [giant] batteries with you to restore power to doors and such. So overall although they did mix it up and add some spice to the gameplay, its still primarily an (almost) outdated FPS.The storyline is lacking, but certainly has some [randomly] brash lines, and decent voice acting. The protagonist has solid voice acting actually, in fact, one of the better voices I've heard considering the lines he was reading were complete ♥♥♥♥ half of the time. Some of the other characters sound like they read one line per day with the same inflection and different words, particularly the foreign guy without much experience in English.The most memorable and worthy lines of the game, that convinced me to keep playing during a hard and honestly boring part:"Arnold, you'll have to hold them off just a little bit longer!!!", says the other character while he was hacking a computer-motherboard-mainframe-core-system to save both of their lives."Why? So you can finish surfing porn?" Arnold is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and a badass even when a tech guru is saving his life and he is shotgunning 20 dudes at once.The game is hard, like 2007 hard. I'm saying like you can't just play this game through casually on normal difficulty because people will actually hit you with most of their bullets and rockets (Although, even in the hands of the villain, the flamethrower sucks ♥♥♥ unless you're stuck in an elevator with them). TL;DR:I know I've just expressed a lot of conflicting like and dislike for this game, but that's how it feels to play it overall, you like it, and then you kind of wish you didn't spend an hour playing it, especially when you forget to save for a half hour and then get smoked by a big fat robot rocket. Slow, tactful, diverse. Enjoy.

												Alpha Prime is a fairly interesting game, it's a sci-fi FPS that takes elements from games such as Doom 3 and Quake 4 (Even the aesthetic of the game will remind you of them) and implements some of its own little things here and there. At first it does seem cliche and it kind of is but players will soon find that there is a very slight supernatural element to the game that affects the psyche of all the people surrounding Alpha Prime, turning them into deranged madmen and making the base's AI go nuts and the Corporation is on clean up duty. Your job is to save your friend who's stranded on Alpha Prime.Unlike most shooters that take a more old school approach (health packs, hip fire, carrying a full arsenal, etc), on normal difficulty the enemies hit very hard which will require you to take a more tactical approach to combat situations which will encourage you to use the lean function as well as the remote control mechanic, allowing you to hack into devices such as cameras, gun turrets, doors and other electronic devices. So since that little introduction is out of the way, now I'll start the review and first I'll break it down into lists of pros and cons to make this review a lot more straight forward:Pros:- Fun and solid gunplay- Nice visual effects- Cool art style- Graphics still look good even today- No regenerating health, all done with medkits and health stations- You can fire from the hip (Always good to have)- Characters have a bit of personality to them- Level design is pretty good- The soundtrack is just awesome- Enemy AI are quite intelligent, always seeking cover, trying to outsmart and outgun you whenever possible and will rush you when they have the chance- A nice array of weapons to use (A gatling-based assault rifle is pretty awesome)- The remote control is cool and fun to use, turning gun turrets against your foes is always fun- Very challenging, will crush gamers who are used to modern FPS and regenerating healthCons:- The story could have been really cool but it was fairly bland and the cliffhanger didn't help either- Bullet time and flamethrower are near enough useless except for the last boss- Enemy placement can be very cheap at times making the difficulty feel very artificial- Enemy variety is near enough non-existant, just different guys with different guns and some robots- Weapons given to the player have pretty poor pacing, it gives you every gun near enough from the get go- The remote control mechanic is too underutilized, you'll often forget you have it later in the game- Voice acting can be pretty atrocious sometimes- The one vehicle segment is just awful, it controls like crap and you can't even run enemies over with it- Enemies have pinpoint accuracy to the point where it's unfair at times (And you can't even dodge their shots in bullet time, yes it's that useless)- Some character models look creepy, making the main character look like a plastic action figure- Cutscenes and dialogue segments go on for WAY too long and when you need to do something, you can't pause them but thankfully they can be skipped- The game only runs for the best part of 4 hours, for a single player only game that will be far too short for mostThe game has a lot of flaws, but it's nowhere near as incompetent like games such as The Stalin Subway and Dusk 12 (Which I did enjoy somewhat). It's not awful by any stretch, some people will love what Black Element did with the game, others may not. It really comes down to a matter of opinion and my opinion is that I really enjoyed it, as short as it was, it was a fun little sci-fi romp with lots of action, somewhat interesting characters and cool aesthetic. It's a shame the remote control was barely ever used and the game was very unbalanced at times but it was a fun game to play as the afternoon or evening just wizzes by.I do recommend this game to those who enjoyed old school shooters or for those who will enjoy something that makes players take a more tactical approach to their combat strategy, for me the positives outweigh the negatives and since I'm a sap for obscure FPS games, there is a chance I will like it for it's quirk. For those who prefer modern FPS with highly linear levels and the overuse of iron sights and regenerating health then this really isn't for you. But if you like kickass FPS soundtracks then this game is great to have, it has some truly fantastic music in there that just gets you really pumped for the action, big kudos to the composer! I'll wrap this up now though, it's on sale now for £0.59 or your regional equivalent and that will give 4 hours of great sci-fi action. I'd say it's worth picking up.

												Alpha Prime is a first person shooter set primarly within the titular facility, Alpha Prime. The game is something like a cross between Red Faction and Quake 4, but not nearly as good as either one.Visuals - The graphics are definitely one of the game's strongpoints. It looks great, and I really don't have anything to say against it.Story - The story is lame and entirely forgettable. Honestly, I hardly cared about what was even going on in the story while playing. It's the same guy-gets-sent-to-abandoned-facility-to-investigate-and-then-gets-trapped scenario we've seen countless times. Several characters are met, they try to work together to find a way off the asteroid, trust is questioned, relationships are strained, lame villain goes after artifact of mystical power, obvious traitor is revealed, etc. The characters are forgettable, and the writing is particularly awful, often leaving me staring slack-jawed at the screen wondering what the game was even trying to convey to me. It can certainly lead to some amusing cutscenes and dialogue, though. It's kinda one of those "so bad its good" things, except rather than "so bad its good", it's more "so bad it's passable and just enough to keep the game moving forward."Sound - Mixed bag here. Let's go over the voice acting first: It's awful, but in a hilarious way. Some of the conversations heard in the game can be amusing just because of how poor the writing and acting is, and Livia's voice constantly sounds like it's coming over a communication device, even if she's in the same room as you are, which I found very strange. On the other hand, the music is actually quite good, especially in the later levels. The good tracks usually start playing when enemies are sighted and you start shooting, and they do a good job of getting you immersed into the action.Gameplay - For the most part, it's typical FPS fare. Most levels are spent traversing rooms and corridors gunning down enemies, hitting a switch to open a door nearby, etc. The game is very linear, levels are a fairly straight path for the most part, with the exception of a few very small detours to hit a switch, or pick up and replace a broken circuit. There are 7 or 8 different weapons, and you'll find yourself with the full arsenal fairly quickly. Health does not regenerate, and you must find medkits or use med-stations on the walls to heal yourself (If you've played Quake 4, it's exactly like that) You have a hacking device which allows you to gain access to various machines that are within range, including cameras, gun turrets and even mines. Unfortunately, your chances to use it on anything besides cameras are few and far between, so its usefulness is fairly limited. This was an interesting idea that they could have done a lot more with. Some people have knocked the game for being very difficult, but those people simply don't know how to play. The enemy accuracy is EXTREMELY high, even at a good distance, they will likely hit you dead-on, and running into a room full of enemies guns-a-blazing is suicide. As I played, though, I discovered the usefulness of the lean function. By hiding behind cover and leaning out to shoot, enemy accuracy was pretty much cut in half. I took far less damage this way and it made the rest of the game fairly easy to complete. The game also has a bulletime function, which slows down the action and can help a bit, but I personally didn't use it too much. Thankfully, the controls won't be adding to your death total, because the game's controls are tight, aside from one of the late levels where you have to drive a vehicle across outdoor terrain. The controls felt slightly delayed, and the game wasn't lagging at all, everything was playing a top speed. I adjusted quickly, however, and this is the only level that has this. Another problem is that the collision detection between you and objects is a bit wonky. There are a few parts where you must jump over crates or onto other objects, and your character will be struggling to get over them as something seemingly pushes him back. Thankfully, moments like this are relatively few, so it's only an occasional annoyance. The game is also very short, clocking in at around 5 hours, though with the game's forgettable story and characters, I honestly see the short length as a positive rather than a negative.Final - Alpha Prime is, overall, a fairly mixed bag. Great visuals, mostly functional controls, good music, but completely forgettable story, lame characters, very short length and pretty much no replay value whatsoever. If you look past the horrible story and characters, the game will provide some decent entertainment for a few hours. If the game was any higher than its asking price of $4.99, I wouldn't be able to recommend it because it's certainly not worth any more than that. I recommend either playing the demo to make sure you'll enjoy it before dropping the 5, or just wait for a discount and get it for a buck or two.

I wouldn't go into the plot since steam already has it. As an overview, I am going to say that this game has a feel of an old school shooter. Health do not regenerate and health packs are needed, replenishing your oxygen supply is also in order out in martian soil. One is able to carry around 7-8 weapons, going around getting creative on how you want to kill your next enemy. Oh, and sometimes out in martian environment, you get to drive a jeep of some sort. Graphics are as that of the 2000s, not great but bearable, not bad for a 2007 game, but we all seen better. The sound wise, loops and loops of action music played through when you are dealing with enemies, voice acting is OK, although sometimes it can be quite laughable.Next I am going to list the Pros and the Cons of this game.PROS:old school shooterchallenging (due many factors)explorable environments and multiple entry points and ways to begin a gunfightget to play with a lot of weaponsintriguing storylineno gore (if you do not like gore)CONS:overpowered enemies (contributes to it being challenging)lack of health packs lying around (you need them due to OP enemies and this contributes to it being challenging)repetitive gameplay (explore, shoot people, find important plot points, shoot more people!)linear gameplay (kind of expected in a 2000's game)loopy music (can  get on your nerves)no gore (if you LOVE gore)In conclusion, I would not recommend this game in the current age, although if you are one of those people that would fancy yourself a challenge or you are into that kind of old school shooter style. If you want a relaxing game you can shoot people in the face without really worrying about health, this game is totally not for you.I may have left out a few pointers here and there, would love some comments and feedback on my reviews so improvements are in order.

												I got this as part of some Humble Bundle, and at one point, I played it. And even though this game really suffers from an inherent lack of polish, I found myself really wanting to like this game. It bring some solid concepts forward to the table as a shooter, such as the hacking interface. It's sort of like Watchdogs as an FPS with this; scan security cameras to check enemy locations and numbers, set up environmental hazards up for remote detonated traps, and even use some of the machinery for surprise attacks. It has good ideas... BUT...There's a lot wrong with this game. On a presentation scale, it's easily the worst part about the game. For a game released in '07, it looks like it comes from '02, and really doesn't have a lot of the aged visuals that can still look good in the modern day with games like, for instance, Unreal Tournament '99. The voice acting is atrociously bad, though it sounds more like bad localization and English dubs, and a lot of the sound quality is atrocious.Gunplay is enjoyable, and some of the weapon designs like the gatling rifle and the sniper rifle are appealing, but the difficulty is extremely harsh, and the AI is pretty unforgiving. Even with patches to fix this, it still does put a damper on the gameplay as a whole.So, I still do find myself really wanting to like this. It's a decently interesting package that does seem appealing, but suffers from some serious issues that drag it down hard. There are definitely other games out there more worth your money, but if it shows up in a good Humble Bundle or something, maybe give it a gander.

												I'm surprised that this game was actually playable and enjoyable, given its poor reputation and not so fond memories of it.The movement is wonky, physics are glitchy, checkpoints are all messed up and story is shallow like a summer puddle. Yet I had fun with it thanks to the good weapon handling [even though hammer and flamethrower were utterly useless, and shotgun and grenades had limited usabilty], hits on target were clearly visible, and the damage- while a bit low, seemed to heave enough force. Some of the better mechanics were definitely this funny "hack vision" and bullet time. The first allowed for some alternative ways to dispose of enemies [shame that level designers completely ignored the potentials it granted, and stopped including it halfway through the game] and gain some view on enemies through cameras; bullet time was used as a rather scarce resource that could grant you a bit more of an upper hand at some of the more dangerous situations, like hard shots or full rooms, so it felt like a fun trump card instead of a core mechanic.While I found it fun, I can't disagree that it would have benefitted from different design decisions, for example: fov slider, smarter level design [this hack thing could have provided some neat secret stashes around the levels if they weren't so straight forward], more and better balanced weapons, more frequent checkpoints, so you don't save all the time, or "use" function on stray medikits, since you could've picked up a huge health boost for little damage by accident. The last boss is also ridiculously bad, it's just: activate 3 terminals, laugh at the "grand challenge"'s poor aim with rocket launcher [enemies are terrible with it as it's not a hitscan weapon they're so used to], while spamming rockets at his face, taking no damage even though the room is cramped, and finally flip the final switch when he wants to cool down for a bit. So it's poorly designed, buggy and wonky, the story is dumb, it's short and the music is boring. Yet it's a fun to play single player FPS, that I can recommend for a low price.

												Alpha Prime is a first person shooter set primarly within the titular facility, Alpha Prime. The game is something like a cross between Red Faction and Quake 4, but not nearly as good as either one.Visuals - The graphics are definitely one of the game's strongpoints. It looks great, and I really don't have anything to say against it.Story - The story is lame and entirely forgettable. Honestly, I hardly cared about what was even going on in the story while playing. It's the same guy-gets-sent-to-abandoned-facility-to-investigate-and-then-gets-trapped scenario we've seen countless times. Several characters are met, they try to work together to find a way off the asteroid, trust is questioned, relationships are strained, lame villain goes after artifact of mystical power, obvious traitor is revealed, etc. The characters are forgettable, and the writing is particularly awful, often leaving me staring slack-jawed at the screen wondering what the game was even trying to convey to me. It can certainly lead to some amusing cutscenes and dialogue, though. It's kinda one of those "so bad its good" things, except rather than "so bad its good", it's more "so bad it's passable and just enough to keep the game moving forward."Sound - Mixed bag here. Let's go over the voice acting first: It's awful, but in a hilarious way. Some of the conversations heard in the game can be amusing just because of how poor the writing and acting is, and Livia's voice constantly sounds like it's coming over a communication device, even if she's in the same room as you are, which I found very strange. On the other hand, the music is actually quite good, especially in the later levels. The good tracks usually start playing when enemies are sighted and you start shooting, and they do a good job of getting you immersed into the action.Gameplay - For the most part, it's typical FPS fare. Most levels are spent traversing rooms and corridors gunning down enemies, hitting a switch to open a door nearby, etc. The game is very linear, levels are a fairly straight path for the most part, with the exception of a few very small detours to hit a switch, or pick up and replace a broken circuit. There are 7 or 8 different weapons, and you'll find yourself with the full arsenal fairly quickly. Health does not regenerate, and you must find medkits or use med-stations on the walls to heal yourself (If you've played Quake 4, it's exactly like that) You have a hacking device which allows you to gain access to various machines that are within range, including cameras, gun turrets and even mines. Unfortunately, your chances to use it on anything besides cameras are few and far between, so its usefulness is fairly limited. This was an interesting idea that they could have done a lot more with. Some people have knocked the game for being very difficult, but those people simply don't know how to play. The enemy accuracy is EXTREMELY high, even at a good distance, they will likely hit you dead-on, and running into a room full of enemies guns-a-blazing is suicide. As I played, though, I discovered the usefulness of the lean function. By hiding behind cover and leaning out to shoot, enemy accuracy was pretty much cut in half. I took far less damage this way and it made the rest of the game fairly easy to complete. The game also has a bulletime function, which slows down the action and can help a bit, but I personally didn't use it too much. Thankfully, the controls won't be adding to your death total, because the game's controls are tight, aside from one of the late levels where you have to drive a vehicle across outdoor terrain. The controls felt slightly delayed, and the game wasn't lagging at all, everything was playing a top speed. I adjusted quickly, however, and this is the only level that has this. Another problem is that the collision detection between you and objects is a bit wonky. There are a few parts where you must jump over crates or onto other objects, and your character will be struggling to get over them as something seemingly pushes him back. Thankfully, moments like this are relatively few, so it's only an occasional annoyance. The game is also very short, clocking in at around 5 hours, though with the game's forgettable story and characters, I honestly see the short length as a positive rather than a negative.Final - Alpha Prime is, overall, a fairly mixed bag. Great visuals, mostly functional controls, good music, but completely forgettable story, lame characters, very short length and pretty much no replay value whatsoever. If you look past the horrible story and characters, the game will provide some decent entertainment for a few hours. If the game was any higher than its asking price of $4.99, I wouldn't be able to recommend it because it's certainly not worth any more than that. I recommend either playing the demo to make sure you'll enjoy it before dropping the 5, or just wait for a discount and get it for a buck or two.

												Alpha Prime (Released: 7 Nov 2007, Acquired: 23 Jan 2014)Given that I got the game in 2014 (7 YEARS after release), this game still has much kick being put into it. I wouldn't go into the plot since steam already has it. As an overview, I am going to say that this game has a feel of an old school shooter. Health do not regenerate and health packs are needed, replenishing your oxygen supply is also in order out in martian soil. One is able to carry around 7-8 weapons, going around getting creative on how you want to kill your next enemy. Oh, and sometimes out in martian environment, you get to drive a jeep of some sort. Graphics are as that of the 2000s, not great but bearable, not bad for a 2007 game, but we all seen better. The sound wise, loops and loops of action music played through when you are dealing with enemies, voice acting is OK, although sometimes it can be quite laughable.Next I am going to list the Pros and the Cons of this game.PROS:old school shooterchallenging (due many factors)explorable environments and multiple entry points and ways to begin a gunfightget to play with a lot of weaponsintriguing storylineno gore (if you do not like gore)CONS:overpowered enemies (contributes to it being challenging)lack of health packs lying around (you need them due to OP enemies and this contributes to it being challenging)repetitive gameplay (explore, shoot people, find important plot points, shoot more people!)linear gameplay (kind of expected in a 2000's game)loopy music (can  get on your nerves)no gore (if you LOVE gore)In conclusion, I would not recommend this game in the current age, although if you are one of those people that would fancy yourself a challenge or you are into that kind of old school shooter style. If you want a relaxing game you can shoot people in the face without really worrying about health, this game is totally not for you.I may have left out a few pointers here and there, would love some comments and feedback on my reviews so improvements are in order.

												You know that feeling when you're one of the rare people that have heard of a certain game, and at the same time, one of the even rarer people that finished it ? Feels good.Many, MANY reviews on here claim that this game is god-awful, not even worth a dollar. It's definitely no masterpiece, but as far as mid-00's first person shooters go, it's very decent.Pros : Gameplay is decent. Weapons feel powerful and ARE powerful, except for the flamethrower which has a pitiful range and does next to no damage (so it's a straight downgrade from the shotgun in that regard) and the hammer, which you will never, ever use in this game except to retrieve extinguishers and fooling around with corpses and windows. The level design is (relatively) really good, in a linear first person shooter manner; I honestly wasn't expecting that. Graphics are on par with their time. Of course, by that point, Doom 3, Far Cry and Fear were all already released so compared to them it's really nothing special, but they're serviceable. Rock soundtrack's nice. Just lower the music volume a bit, you'll thank me later. The story, characters and dialogue are hilariously ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Just grab a drink and don't take any of it seriously. Remember, believe in Glomar and prevent Bellini from becoming a tortellini. Also, Bruce survives at the end and gets together with Weiss, and there's nothing you can do to make me believe otherwise. Seriously, Bruce's dialogue towards Weiss and his animosity towards Livia is beyond "implying" territory. Roughly five hours of content. It doesn't outstay its welcome.Cons : I have experienced two or three crashes and one game-breaking bug where I had to find a battery to open a door, but the battery was behind another door that was open to me five minutes earlier, but not in the moment, for some reason. Solved it by restarting the level and bringing the battery just in front of the door even before the game told me I'd need one. Story and dialogue are REALLY ♥♥♥♥♥♥. That doesn't bother me in this case, but peeps that can't stand B-movie stuff will be ♥♥♥♥♥♥. They tried to copy/paste some elements from other popular FPS games of the time to see what would stick, and it shows. Hello, useless bullet time from F.E.A.R. Never used you once, never felt the need to. On the matter of level variety, all you're gonna get is metal corridors and Mars hellscape. I liked it, though. Again, roughly five hours of content, and that's after exploring every nook and cranny, restarting some levels and getting lost at one point because of a bug. Extremely short by the standards of that era's shooters. You'll finish it in 4 hours or less if you're experienced, you don't get bugs or glitches, and you instinctively know where to go at any given time. The enemies' accuracy is off the damn charts, and that's what people here hate the most, it seems. Again, that never bothered me. There are just some things to know : One, the "lean" buttons are there for a reason. Use them. They will aim center of mass, not at your head; take potshots around corners and boxes whenever possible. Two, headshots are really easy to pull off in this game for some reason. Three, never, EVER come close to a bot or a shotgun grunt.P.S. : People seem to think this game has an ammo shortage problem. Don't know what they're about, I had a full inventory of everything but the assault rifle and the rocket launcher before I fought the final boss. If you can't aim or if you can't conserve ammo properly, don't blame it on the game, guys !
